docs.lead_paragraph: Women with uncomplicated pregnancies are better off with midwives, as hospitalization increased the chances of surgical intervention and infection, guidelines suggested.

headline.main: British Regulator Urges Home Births Over Hospitals for Uncomplicated Pregnancies
headline.print_headline: British Regulator Urges Home Births Over Hospitals for Uncomplicated Pregnancies

docs.abstract: Britain’s national health service advises healthy women that it is safer to have their babies at home, or in a birth center, than in hospital, reversing generation of guidance on childbirth; data shows that women with uncomplicated births, 45 percent of total, are more likely to be given cesarean sections in hospital.
docs.snippet: Women with uncomplicated pregnancies are better off with midwives, as hospitalization increased the chances of surgical intervention and infection, guidelines suggested.

byline.contributor: Katrin Bennhold reported from London, and Catherine Saint Louis from New York.
byline.original: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday replaced a system that officials described as confusing and outdated with a clearer, more consistent explanation of dangers.

headline.main: F.D.A. Revamps System Explaining the Risks of Medicines During Pregnancy
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Updates System Explaining the Dangers of Medicines Taken During Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration updates system of how drug companies must explain dangers of taking medicine during pregnancy and while breast-feeding; doctors say current system, developed in 1970s and using letters of alphabet to indicate levels of risk, is too vague.
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday replaced a system that officials described as confusing and outdated with a clearer, more consistent explanation of dangers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court wrestled with what to make of language in the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, which governs how employers must treat pregnant workers.

headline.main: UPS Suit Hinges on an Ambiguous Pregnancy Law
headline.print_headline: UPS Suit Hinges on an Ambiguous Pregnancy Law

docs.abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments in pregnancy discrimination case against United Parcel Service; former UPS driver Peggy Young is suing under federal Pregnancy Discrimination Act, after company refused to assign her to lighter duty during her pregnancy; suit hinges on questions about scope of required workplace accommodations for pregnant women.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court wrestled with what to make of language in the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, which governs how employers must treat pregnant workers.

headline.main: Today in Small Business: Pregnancy Discrimination

docs.abstract: Private-sector hiring fell shy of estimates in November. There is big business in ugly Christmas sweaters. And the value of the world’s largest truffle.
docs.snippet: Private-sector hiring fell shy of estimates in November. There is big business in ugly Christmas sweaters. And the value of the world’s largest truffle.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women are about to get easier-to-understand information on how safe their medicine is for baby.

headline.main: Pregnant Women to Get Better Info on Drug Risks
headline.print_headline: Pregnant Women to Get Better Info on Drug Risks

docs.snippet: Pregnant women are about to get easier-to-understand information on how safe their medicine is for baby.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Supreme Court justices appeared unsure on Wednesday how to decide a case that could determine whether employers must provide accommodations for pregnant workers who may have physical limitations on duties they can perform.

headline.main: U.S. Justices Grapple With UPS Pregnancy Discrimination Case
headline.print_headline: U.S. Justices Grapple With UPS Pregnancy Discrimination Case

docs.snippet: U.S. Supreme Court justices appeared unsure on Wednesday how to decide a case that could determine whether employers must provide accommodations for pregnant workers who may have physical limitations on duties they can perform.

docs.abstract: The Supreme Court hears arguments regarding the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court hears arguments regarding the Pregnancy Discrimination Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two of the three women on the Supreme Court vigorously questioned a UPS lawyer Wednesday over the company's refusal to give lighter duty to a pregnant worker, a closely watched case with potentially broad impact for female workers and their employers.

headline.main: Justices Weigh Bias Claim of Pregnant UPS Driver
headline.print_headline: Justices Weigh Bias Claim of Pregnant UPS Driver
